elements.content: A dendritic aromatic 12-carboxyl ligand (H12TDDPB) is assembled with Zn(II) ion. The TDDPB dimer coordinated with 12 Zn(II) ions, regarded as a dodecapus, is stabilized by metal coordination and π–π stacking. The dodecapus-based framework presents a new type of topology (hhm) with the point symbol of (6·8·10)3(63·8·10·12)3(63)7. The resulting material emits strong blue luminescence in DMF, while the maximum emission of free ligand H12TDDPB is in the ultraviolet region.
elements.clean_text: A dendritic aromatic 12-carboxyl ligand (H12TDDPB) is assembled with Zn(II) ion. The TDDPB dimer coordinated with 12 Zn(II) ions, regarded as a dodecapus, is stabilized by metal coordination and π-π stacking. The dodecapus-based framework presents a new type of topology (hhm) with the point symbol of (6⋅8⋅10)3(63⋅8⋅10⋅12)3(63)7. The resulting material emits strong blue luminescence in DMF, while the maximum emission of free ligand H12TDDPB is in the ultraviolet region.

elements.content: A dendritic aromatic 12-carboxyl ligand (H12TDDPB) is assembled with Zn(II) ion. The TDDPB dimer coordinated with 12 Zn(II) ions, regarded as a dodecapus, is stabilized by metal coordination and π−π stacking. The resulting material emits strong blue luminescence in DMF, while the maximum emission of free ligand H12TDDPB is in the ultraviolet region.
elements.clean_text: A dendritic aromatic 12-carboxyl ligand (H12TDDPB) is assembled with Zn(II) ion. The TDDPB dimer coordinated with 12 Zn(II) ions, regarded as a dodecapus, is stabilized by metal coordination and π-π stacking. The resulting material emits strong blue luminescence in DMF, while the maximum emission of free ligand H12TDDPB is in the ultraviolet region.

elements.content: In nature, many structurally complicated and functional molecular architectures can be formed by integrating intra- and/or intermolecular noncovalent interactions. One of the most famous examples is the double-helical structure of DNA stabilized by hydrogen bonding and π–π stacking. Natural systems motivate scientists to seek new methods to obtain elaborate molecular assemblies. Interestingly, the assembly of metal ion/cluster and organic ligand by coordination can form very beautiful framework patterns. Many functionalities, such as absorption, separation, sensing, catalysis, etc., have been endowed to the metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) characteristic of porosity.
elements.clean_text: In nature, many structurally complicated and functional molecular architectures can be formed by integrating intra- and/or intermolecular noncovalent interactions. One of the most famous examples is the double-helical structure of DNA stabilized by hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking. Natural systems motivate scientists to seek new methods to obtain elaborate molecular assemblies. Interestingly, the assembly of metal ion/cluster and organic ligand by coordination can form very beautiful framework patterns. Many functionalities, such as absorption, separation, sensing, catalysis, etc., have been endowed to the metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) characteristic of porosity.

elements.content: Recently, some 6- and 8-carboxyl dendritic ligands have been applied to build up novel MOFs. More plentiful topologies and robust functionalities have been presented. However, it is very scarce until now to explore the assembly of a ligand containing larger than eight carboxyl groups with a metal ion/cluster. Mohamed Eddaoudi et al. have synthesized a flexible 12-carboxyl ligand, 5,5′,5″,5‴,5″″,5‴″-[1,2,3,4,5,6-phenylhexamethoxy]hexaisophthalic acid. When it assembles with Cu(II) ion, only eight carboxyl groups are used to connect a tbo topology, and another four ones are suspended. If such carboxyl groups (>8) in one ligand together join the work to connect a framework, the space between ligands seems to become overcrowded. Evidently, it is a quite interesting and challenging job to produce such a MOF in crystal engineering. Furthermore, it also could be expected to obtain varieties of intriguing molecular architectures or fascinating topological structures.
elements.clean_text: Recently, some 6- and 8-carboxyl dendritic ligands have been applied to build up novel MOFs. More plentiful topologies and robust functionalities have been presented. However, it is very scarce until now to explore the assembly of a ligand containing larger than eight carboxyl groups with a metal ion/cluster. Mohamed Eddaoudi et al. have synthesized a flexible 12-carboxyl ligand, 5,5',5",5‴,5"",5‴"-[1,2,3,4,5,6-phenylhexamethoxy]hexaisophthalic acid. When it assembles with Cu(II) ion, only eight carboxyl groups are used to connect a tbo topology, and another four ones are suspended. If such carboxyl groups (>8) in one ligand together join the work to connect a framework, the space between ligands seems to become overcrowded. Evidently, it is a quite interesting and challenging job to produce such a MOF in crystal engineering. Furthermore, it also could be expected to obtain varieties of intriguing molecular architectures or fascinating topological structures.

elements.content: In our previous work, a 6-node dendritic ligand 1,3,5-tris(3,5-di(4-carboxylphenyl-1-yl)phenyl-1-yl)benzene has been utilized to assemble with different metal clusters, which form a new derived net (jjt). To our interest, how does a 12-carboxyl ligand based on the same core structure, 1,3,5-tris(3,5-di(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl-1-yl)phenyl-1-yl)benzene (H 12 TDDPB, Scheme ), assemble with a metal ion/cluster? In this communication, we introduce the very charming dodecapus-based assembly behavior of ligand H 12 TDDPB and Zn(II) ion. This resulting material generates a new type of topology (hhm) and also exhibits interesting and important fluorescent properties.
elements.clean_text: In our previous work, a 6-node dendritic ligand 1,3,5-tris(3,5-di(4-carboxylphenyl-1-yl)phenyl-1-yl)benzene has been utilized to assemble with different metal clusters, which form a new derived net (jjt). To our interest, how does a 12-carboxyl ligand based on the same core structure, 1,3,5-tris(3,5-di(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl-1-yl)phenyl-1-yl)benzene (H  12  TDDPB, Scheme ), assemble with a metal ion/cluster? In this communication, we introduce the very charming dodecapus-based assembly behavior of ligand H  12  TDDPB and Zn(II) ion. This resulting material generates a new type of topology (hhm) and also exhibits interesting and important fluorescent properties.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Twelve-Carboxyl Ligand <bold>H</bold>
<sub>
<bold>12</bold>
</sub>
<bold>TDDPB</bold>
</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="cg-2014-01012e_0006.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Ligand H 12 TDDPB was obtained by a Suzuki coupling reaction of 1,3,5-tris(3′,5′-dibormophenyl)benzene and 3,5-dicarbomethoxyphenylboronic acid pinacol ester and subsequent saponification and acidification (see ). The solvated form of JUC-124 ([H2N(CH3)2]6[Zn3(TDDPB)]·2DMF) (JUC = Jilin University, China) as colorless polyhedral crystal was successfully synthesized by heating ligand H 12 TDDPB with Zn(NO3)2·6H2O in a mixed solvent of DMF and water (80/20, v/v) for 72 h at 85 °C. The H2N(CH3)2 is produced by the hydrolysis of DMF. Single crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that JUC-124 crystallizes in R3̅ space group. The asymmetrical unit of the host framework includes one Zn(II) ion and one-third of a TDDPB ligand (Figure S1, ). Each Zn(II) ion is five-coordinated with four carboxyl units from three ligands (Figure S2, ). Notably, the coordinated oxygen atoms O1 and O5 come from two different carboxyl groups in one ligand, thus forming three intramolecular coordination rings (Figure a). The ligand remains a C 3 symmetry, and all carboxyl groups are connected with nine Zn(II) ions to form a 3D framework.
elements.clean_text: Ligand H  12  TDDPB was obtained by a Suzuki coupling reaction of 1,3,5-tris(3',5'-dibormophenyl)benzene and 3,5-dicarbomethoxyphenylboronic acid pinacol ester and subsequent saponification and acidification (see ). The solvated form of JUC-124 ([H2N(CH3)2]6[Zn3(TDDPB)]⋅2DMF) (JUC = Jilin University, China) as colorless polyhedral crystal was successfully synthesized by heating ligand H  12  TDDPB with Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O in a mixed solvent of DMF and water (80/20, v/v) for 72 h at 85 °C. The H2N(CH3)2 is produced by the hydrolysis of DMF. Single crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that JUC-124 crystallizes in R3̅ space group. The asymmetrical unit of the host framework includes one Zn(II) ion and one-third of a TDDPB ligand (Figure S1, ). Each Zn(II) ion is five-coordinated with four carboxyl units from three ligands (Figure S2, ). Notably, the coordinated oxygen atoms O1 and O5 come from two different carboxyl groups in one ligand, thus forming three intramolecular coordination rings (Figure a). The ligand remains a C 3 symmetry, and all carboxyl groups are connected with nine Zn(II) ions to form a 3D framework.

elements.content: (a) TDDPB ligand in JUC-124; (b,c) the dodecapus formed by two TDDPB ligands along different directions (b and c); (d) two adjacent dodecapuses connecting with two Zn(II) bridges. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. C, gray; O, red; Zn, green.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) TDDPB ligand in JUC-124; (b,c) the dodecapus formed by two TDDPB ligands along different directions (b and c); (d) two adjacent dodecapuses connecting with two Zn(II) bridges. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. C, gray; O, red; Zn, green.

elements.content: Furthermore, a TDDPB dimer is formed by six Zn(II) bridges, and each Zn(II) bridge is bound with three oxygen atoms from O1, O5 of one ligand, and O3 of another one (Figure b,c). This TDDPB dimer is altogether coordinated with 12 Zn(II) ions, thus forming a dodecapus-like cluster. Especially, there exist strong π–π stacking interactions between the two ligands (Figure S3, ). One sandwich benzene dimer parallel to (001) plane with the distance of ∼3.47 Å was observed in the center of the dodecapus, and six approximately parallel-displaced benzene dimers with the distance of ∼3.61 Å in the peripheral. The interactions between two ligands result in the coplanarization of aromatic rings, and the dihedral angles between two phenyl rings in all biphenyl units are around 30°. To the best of our knowledge, the dodecapus-like self-assembly pattern has not been reported so far.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, a TDDPB dimer is formed by six Zn(II) bridges, and each Zn(II) bridge is bound with three oxygen atoms from O1, O5 of one ligand, and O3 of another one (Figure b,c). This TDDPB dimer is altogether coordinated with 12 Zn(II) ions, thus forming a dodecapus-like cluster. Especially, there exist strong π-π stacking interactions between the two ligands (Figure S3, ). One sandwich benzene dimer parallel to (001) plane with the distance of ~3.47 Å was observed in the center of the dodecapus, and six approximately parallel-displaced benzene dimers with the distance of ~3.61 Å in the peripheral. The interactions between two ligands result in the coplanarization of aromatic rings, and the dihedral angles between two phenyl rings in all biphenyl units are around 30°. To the best of our knowledge, the dodecapus-like self-assembly pattern has not been reported so far.

elements.content: Two adjacent dodecapuses are connected by two Zn(II) bridges (Figure d). Each dodecapus is surrounded by six from different directions. Thus, a noninterpenetrated network with channels in three dimensions is formed (Figure S4, ). Moreover, eight parts of separate dodcapus form a cage with 12 windows (Figure S5, ). The dimension of the cage is about 1.8 nm × 1.8 nm. In the MOF structure, only one side of the polyphenyl chromophore is exposed to the cavity. After elimination of guest molecules, the total accessible volume in JUC-124 is 58.0% using the PLATON/VOID routine, and the calculated framework density is 0.835 g cm–3. From the topologic point of view, the Zn(II) ion and TDDPB ligand can be regarded as 4-node and 12-node unit, respectively (Figure ). The resulting 3D network can be symbolized as a new type of topology (hhm) with the point symbol of (6·8·10)3(63·8·10·12)3(63)7. Very interestingly, if two Zn(II) bridges connecting with two different dodecapuses were shrunk into a node, a dodecapus can be seen as a 6-connected octahedral unit and JUC-124 is simplified as a (6,6)-connected pcu topology (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: Two adjacent dodecapuses are connected by two Zn(II) bridges (Figure d). Each dodecapus is surrounded by six from different directions. Thus, a noninterpenetrated network with channels in three dimensions is formed (Figure S4, ). Moreover, eight parts of separate dodcapus form a cage with 12 windows (Figure S5, ). The dimension of the cage is about 1.8 nm × 1.8 nm. In the MOF structure, only one side of the polyphenyl chromophore is exposed to the cavity. After elimination of guest molecules, the total accessible volume in JUC-124 is 58.0% using the PLATON/VOID routine, and the calculated framework density is 0.835 g cm-3. From the topologic point of view, the Zn(II) ion and TDDPB ligand can be regarded as 4-node and 12-node unit, respectively (Figure ). The resulting 3D network can be symbolized as a new type of topology (hhm) with the point symbol of (6⋅8⋅10)3(63⋅8⋅10⋅12)3(63)7. Very interestingly, if two Zn(II) bridges connecting with two different dodecapuses were shrunk into a node, a dodecapus can be seen as a 6-connected octahedral unit and JUC-124 is simplified as a (6,6)-connected pcu topology (Figure ).

elements.content: Topology of JUC-124. The Zn(II) ion and TDDPB ligand can be regarded as the 4-node and 12-node unit, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 2  Topology of JUC-124. The Zn(II) ion and TDDPB ligand can be regarded as the 4-node and 12-node unit, respectively.

elements.content: Simplified pcu topology corresponding to the accumulation structure based on dodecapus. The two Zn(II) bridges connecting with two different dodecapuses are shrunk into a node.
elements.clean_text: 3  Simplified pcu topology corresponding to the accumulation structure based on dodecapus. The two Zn(II) bridges connecting with two different dodecapuses are shrunk into a node.

elements.content: A thermogravimetric (TG) curve of the as-synthesized JUC-124 displayed a continuous weight loss of 19.58% before 165 °C, which could be attributed to the loss of guest DMF (calculated value, 19.13 wt %) (Figure S6, ). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses of JUC-124 were carried out at room temperature (Figure S7, ). The result showed that the experimental PXRD pattern was almost identical to the simulated pattern from the single crystal structure, which revealed the phase purity of the bulk crystalline materials. However, there was no N2 or other gas absorption measured for the desolvated JUC-124 because it was easily broken according to the variable temperature PXRD results (Figure S8, ).
elements.clean_text: A thermogravimetric (TG) curve of the as-synthesized JUC-124 displayed a continuous weight loss of 19.58% before 165 °C, which could be attributed to the loss of guest DMF (calculated value, 19.13 wt %) (Figure S6, ). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses of JUC-124 were carried out at room temperature (Figure S7, ). The result showed that the experimental PXRD pattern was almost identical to the simulated pattern from the single crystal structure, which revealed the phase purity of the bulk crystalline materials. However, there was no N2 or other gas absorption measured for the desolvated JUC-124 because it was easily broken according to the variable temperature PXRD results (Figure S8, ).

elements.content: Furthermore, the excitation and emission spectra of JUC-124 crystal powder dispersing in DMF were measured considering that it was insoluble and well kept in DMF. It exhibited an excitation band at 335 nm and displayed strong blue luminescence with an emission band at 435 nm (Figure a). In contrast, the maximum excitation and emission wavelengths of ligand H 12 TDDPB in DMF are at 318 and 370 nm, respectively (Figure a). The spectral red-shift is mainly due to the coplanarization of aromatic rings and the π–π stacking in MOF. In fact, the emission spectrum of JUC-124 crystal powder is similar to that of ligand H 12 TDDPB powder (Figure S9, ), suggesting that there could exist the similar aggregated form in the two solids. Notably, the TDDPB dimer is the only aggregated fluorescent species in JUC-124 crystal.

It exhibited an excitation band at 335 nm and displayed strong blue luminescence with an emission band at 435 nm (Figure a). In contrast, the maximum excitation and emission wavelengths of ligand H  12  TDDPB in DMF are at 318 and 370 nm, respectively (Figure a). The spectral red-shift is mainly due to the coplanarization of aromatic rings and the π-π stacking in MOF. In fact, the emission spectrum of JUC-124 crystal powder is similar to that of ligand H  12  TDDPB powder (Figure S9, ), suggesting that there could exist the similar aggregated form in the two solids. Notably, the TDDPB dimer is the only aggregated fluorescent species in JUC-124 crystal.

elements.content: (a) Excitation (dot) and emission (line) spectra of JUC-124 (blue) and ligand H 12 TDDPB (black, 0.1 mM) in DMF; (b–d) the emission spectra of JUC-124 titrated in DMF with 2,4-DNT (b), 1,3-DNB (c), and NB (d). The insets indicate the Stern–Volmer plot. JUC-124 crystal powder of 4.0 mg was dispersed in DMF of 3.0 mL. DMF, N,N-dimethylformamide; 2,4-DNT, 2,4-dinitrotoluene; 1,3-DNB, 1,3-dinitrobenzene; NB, nitrobenzene.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Excitation (dot) and emission (line) spectra of JUC-124 (blue) and ligand H  12  TDDPB (black, 0.1 mM) in DMF; (b-d) the emission spectra of JUC-124 titrated in DMF with 2,4-DNT (b), 1,3-DNB (c), and NB (d). The insets indicate the Stern-Volmer plot. JUC-124 crystal powder of 4.0 mg was dispersed in DMF of 3.0 mL. DMF, N,N-dimethylformamide; 2,4-DNT, 2,4-dinitrotoluene; 1,3-DNB, 1,3-dinitrobenzene; NB, nitrobenzene.

elements.content: The emission spectra of JUC-124 crystal powder were measured in DMF with different analytes of 0.5 M (Figure S10, ). The fluorescence intensity was slightly enhanced for CH3CN, CH2Cl2, acetone, toluene, and o-xylene and was slightly decreased for benzoic acid, but became very weak for NB, 1,3-DNB, and 2,4-DNT. In order to gain insight into the fluorescence quenching process, JUC-124 was titrated with various nitro aromatics in DMF at room temperature. The ratio (I 0/I) of the fluorescence intensities in the absence and in the presence of quenchers was approximately linearly increased with increasing the concentration of nitro aromatics because of photoinduced electron transfer from polyphenyl to the nitro aromatics (Figure b–d). The Stern–Volmer constant, K SV, was 1.3 × 103 M–1 for 2,4-DNT, 6.0 × 102 M–1 for 1,3-DNB, and 6.9 × 102 M–1 for NB, respectively. The shape of the chromophore and reduction potentials of nitro aromatics could together affect the electron transfer. The JUC-124 powder may be recycled by centrifuging and washing in DMF. The fluorescence intensity of JUC-124 in DMF was almost unchanged after being used at least five times (Figure S11, ).
elements.clean_text: The emission spectra of JUC-124 crystal powder were measured in DMF with different analytes of 0.5 M (Figure S10, ). The fluorescence intensity was slightly enhanced for CH3CN, CH2Cl2, acetone, toluene, and o-xylene and was slightly decreased for benzoic acid, but became very weak for NB, 1,3-DNB, and 2,4-DNT. In order to gain insight into the fluorescence quenching process, JUC-124 was titrated with various nitro aromatics in DMF at room temperature. The ratio (I 0/I) of the fluorescence intensities in the absence and in the presence of quenchers was approximately linearly increased with increasing the concentration of nitro aromatics because of photoinduced electron transfer from polyphenyl to the nitro aromatics (Figure b-d). The Stern-Volmer constant, K SV, was 1.3 × 103 M-1 for 2,4-DNT, 6.0 × 102 M-1 for 1,3-DNB, and 6.9 × 102 M-1 for NB, respectively. The shape of the chromophore and reduction potentials of nitro aromatics could together affect the electron transfer. The JUC-124 powder may be recycled by centrifuging and washing in DMF. The fluorescence intensity of JUC-124 in DMF was almost unchanged after being used at least five times (Figure S11, ).

elements.content: In conclusion, a dendritic 12-carboxyl aromatic ligand has been successfully assembled with Zn(II) ion. All 12 carboxyl groups together join the work to construct a 3D nonpenetrated framework and the formation of dodecapus unit stabilized by metal coordination and π–π stacking. A new type of topology (hhm) with the point symbol of (6·8·10)3(63·8·10·12)3(63)7 was obtained. The resulting MOF material can emit strong blue luminescence, and nitro aromatics can quench it by photoinduced electron-transfer. Very interestingly, the fluorescent property of JUC-124 crystal powder in DMF is similar to that of ligand H 12 TDDPB in solid state. These results indicate that the design of the framework could provide a new way to obtain interesting and useful materials. Further work about the assembly of ligand H 12 TDDPB with other metal ions/clusters is ongoing.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, a dendritic 12-carboxyl aromatic ligand has been successfully assembled with Zn(II) ion. All 12 carboxyl groups together join the work to construct a 3D nonpenetrated framework and the formation of dodecapus unit stabilized by metal coordination and π-π stacking. A new type of topology (hhm) with the point symbol of (6⋅8⋅10)3(63⋅8⋅10⋅12)3(63)7 was obtained. The resulting MOF material can emit strong blue luminescence, and nitro aromatics can quench it by photoinduced electron-transfer. Very interestingly, the fluorescent property of JUC-124 crystal powder in DMF is similar to that of ligand H  12  TDDPB in solid state. These results indicate that the design of the framework could provide a new way to obtain interesting and useful materials. Further work about the assembly of ligand H  12  TDDPB with other metal ions/clusters is ongoing.

elements.content:
Synthesis, X-ray, TGA data; fluorescence and FT-IR spectra; computational study; CIF file. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

References
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis, X-ray, TGA data; fluorescence and FT-IR spectra; computational study; CIF file. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

References

cln_elements.content:
Two adjacent dodecapuses are connected by two Zn(II) bridges (Figure d). Each dodecapus is surrounded by six from different directions. Thus, a noninterpenetrated network with channels in three dimensions is formed (Figure S4, ). Moreover, eight parts of separate dodcapus form a cage with 12 windows (Figure S5, ). The dimension of the cage is about 1.8 nm × 1.8 nm. In the MOF structure, only one side of the polyphenyl chromophore is exposed to the cavity. After elimination of guest molecules, the total accessible volume in JUC-124 is 58.0% using the PLATON/VOID routine, and the calculated framework density is 0.835 g cm–3. From the topologic point of view, the Zn(II) ion and TDDPB ligand can be regarded as 4-node and 12-node unit, respectively (Figure ). The resulting 3D network can be symbolized as a new type of topology (hhm) with the point symbol of (6·8·10)3(63·8·10·12)3(63)7. Very interestingly, if two Zn(II) bridges connecting with two different dodecapuses were shrunk into a node, a dodecapus can be seen as a 6-connected octahedral unit and JUC-124 is simplified as a (6,6)-connected pcu topology (Figure ).

A thermogravimetric (TG) curve of the as-synthesized JUC-124 displayed a continuous weight loss of 19.58% before 165 °C, which could be attributed to the loss of guest DMF (calculated value, 19.13 wt %) (Figure S6, ). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses of JUC-124 were carried out at room temperature (Figure S7, ). The result showed that the experimental PXRD pattern was almost identical to the simulated pattern from the single crystal structure, which revealed the phase purity of the bulk crystalline materials. However, there was no N2 or other gas absorption measured for the desolvated JUC-124 because it was easily broken according to the variable temperature PXRD results (Figure S8, ).

The result showed that the experimental PXRD pattern was almost identical to the simulated pattern from the single crystal structure, which revealed the phase purity of the bulk crystalline materials. However, there was no N2 or other gas absorption measured for the desolvated JUC-124 because it was easily broken according to the variable temperature PXRD results (Figure S8, ).

cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Excitation (dot) and emission (line) spectra of JUC-124 (blue) and ligand H  12  TDDPB (black, 0.1 mM) in DMF; (b-d) the emission spectra of JUC-124 titrated in DMF with 2,4-DNT (b), 1,3-DNB (c), and NB (d). The insets indicate the Stern-Volmer plot. JUC-124 crystal powder of 4.0 mg was dispersed in DMF of 3.0 mL. DMF, N,N-dimethylformamide; 2,4-DNT, 2,4-dinitrotoluene; 1,3-DNB, 1,3-dinitrobenzene; NB, nitrobenzene.
